 Most thinking people can't be bothered giving people like the above the time of day, but I'll try:
 
 Firstly, we creationists are more logical than you think. We beleive what the bible claims; that God created everything (Gen. 1:5, 31; 2:4), right, got that? We also believe what the bible says; God is such a powerful spirit (or force if you want to be scientific) that if any man were to see Him, he'd die! God told one of his faithful worshipers: "No man may see me and yet live." (Exodus 33:20) God is a Spirit, and humans cannot see him with their physical eyes. (John 4:24) Just as looking directly at the sun at midday would be disastrous to our eyes, so it would be devastating for us to see the tremendous source of energy that created not only our brilliant sun but also the countless other suns in the#universe. You think about it, if God made the sun, which has to be an average of 93,000,000 miles away from the earth (in order that we don't burn up!), how powerfull and distant do you think He would have to be from the earth??? If he's that far away do you think that todays scientists are going to reach and detect him with their probes to prove his existance? lol, i don't think so. Man only managed to set foot on the moon just over 30 years ago. Man is still very primative, we know nothing about the universe! And to make a claim that God doesn't exist is more than just stupid. It's as stupid as saying that nobody built your house, and yet that's what people say about the universe (which is much more complex).
 
 The next question would probably be, if God does exist, then why doesn't he give us a sign? After all, He used to perform miracles for Noah, the Isrealites etc, He even sent Jesus down to earth 2000 years ago, so where is he now when the earth needs Him the most??? Well, you'll just have to speak to your local Jehovahs Witness for that answer and many many more (including, what's the purpose of life? Why is there so much suffering in the world?)

I'm not as sad as that. The definition of sad is defending something (evolution) that doesn't have a leg to stand on anymore (fossil evidence doesn't prove evolution). There are that many holes in the evolution theory it's a joke. 

 
 Oh God, not again. You're correct in the fact that the fossil record doesn't prove evolution. Fossils, being the lithified remains of long dead organisms, have great problems providing any evidence on thier genetic make-up. What the fossil record does show is cases where, over time, modifications can be seen in animals morphology. There is also the fact you can find animals which are 'almost' another type of animal. A good example is Synapsids (otherwise known as 'Mammal-like reptiles'). The fossil record provides data which is best explained by the ToE, rather than 'Goddidit'. The argument between ToE and ID is not something in which the fossil record can be involved.
 
 As far as I can tell, you don't talk about God as the personalised deity that most mainstream christian traditions talk about. In fact you seem to have a rather 'hippy-ish' view in that God is an energy. Just so you know, the idea that humans die when seeing Gods goes back at least as far as the ancient Greeks. Zeus killed one of his lovers when she demanded to see him in his true form (just by the power revealed in him). I think she was the mother of Perseus or something....
 
 Just so you know, if God is a force, we've probably already picked him out and got him down as an unexplained physical constant, and if he's a spirit, we can't pick him up scientifically, and therefore aren't trying to prove him or disprove him. It's true that we are not hugely advanced in terms of our understanding, but we are hugely advanced beyond 5-600 years ago, when the christians were doing thier best to burn anyone who asked questions. Nowadays we agree that Gallileo was a very smart man, rather than a heretic. Religion still has a place today, but it no longer directs the entire course of human life.

 You're getting a reply that points out that you don't understand what the theory of evolution means. (Why am I not surprised by this?)
 
 There are a number of developing theories about the origins of living cells. The theory of evolution, however, addresses genetic change between generations of existing organisms, including but not restricted to the divergence of species and other taxa.
 
 If you want to post about abiogenesis, do so and call it that: do not confuse it with the theory of evolution. Your post makes as much sense as saying that gravitational theory is rubbish because it doesn't explain electromagnetism.

 The "roof" that you should put both items under is biology (the study of life). Biology is mostly based on the theory of evolution, but it covers abiogenesis, too.
 As for abiogenesis, consider this site. In particular, consider the quote,"Figure 2. Original cellular genesis in retracement taped by Mr. Randall Grubbs. A large chunk of thermal protein (1000x) is contacted by warm 1.0% sodium chloride solution. On cooling, protocells stream forth in less than two minutes."Abiogenesis isn't yet "proven," but it certainly seems plausible considering that protocells can be reliably made...

To me, the evolution from non living matter to living matter (abiogenesis) and the evolution of existing organisms etc all comes under one roof (i.e. evolution).

 Well then, you're wrong. (You're other things, too, but I'm not allowed to say those things here.) Here's why:
 Let's say God magically poofed the first life into existence. Why does that mean that either (1) life has not evolved since then or (2) we can't possibly know anything about ancient life?
 Even if you make the explicit assumption that abiogenesis did not happen, there is no reason to believe that subsequent evolution hasn't happened.

Actually, we do much more. But the question could be as well put to creationists. You, for example, what is you point in being here.

Personnaly [sic] i think most of you evolutionists on here have way to big egos and act like children.
